page.title: 13NATURAL HISTORY
page.content: The principal habitats in our 'box' are: WOODLAND : Numerous woods remain, and survey work by Hampshire County Council has revealed that many of these can be classified as ancient. Traditional management (notably coppicing) has all but died out, leading to loss of diversity of nesting sites and shading out of ground flora. DOWNLAND : Apart from Brook Quarry none remains as far as we are aware. WATERSIDE : No sizeable areas of watermeadows or grazing meadows remain untampered with, although it is possible to find some quite good flora. The Test itself is virtually inaccessible to the public. The valley has a good barn owl population. The best overall stretch is the Test Way: nightingales, other warblers.
